CASE 58:
PROPHYLACTIC SURGERY
Diane is a 34-year-old police officer. She has been referred to your surgical clinic by her GP as
recent genetic tests have revealed that Diane carries the BRCA 1 gene. These were performed
by the local genetics department as her mum and older sister had both developed breast
cancer in their 40s. Diane has come to request that you list her for surgery to remove both
breasts in an attempt to prevent her from developing breast cancer.
You have never come across someone asking for their breasts to be removed but have heard
several stories in the media where this has been performed in similar circumstances. You
are uncertain about some of the ethical issues regarding her case and tell the patient that
you will consider her request but that you are unable to give her a definite answer yet. You
arrange to see her again in 2 weeks after you have had a chance to discuss her request with
your colleagues and the hospital’s clinical ethics committee.
Question
• Is removal of healthy tissue ever appropriate to prevent disease?

data.vignette: A 34-year-old police officer is referred after testing positive for a pathogenic BRCA1 variant. Her mother and older sister developed breast cancer in their 40s. She has no breast symptoms and her exam and recent imaging are unremarkable. She requests bilateral prophylactic mastectomy with reconstruction and asks to be placed on the surgical schedule. She says she understands the loss of sensation, possible complications, and that surgery cannot eliminate risk. She also says she feels unable to live with repeated screening and the possibility of being diagnosed “too late.” You worry about performing an irreversible operation on healthy tissue and the physical and psychological harms if she later regrets it. Surveillance and risk‑reducing medication are available but would require years of follow-up and ongoing uncertainty. Hospital policy allows either pathway when informed consent is documented. She is leaving the region for a long-term assignment in six weeks, so a plan is needed now.
data.choice_1: List her for bilateral prophylactic mastectomy with reconstruction.
data.choice_2: Decline surgery now and pursue intensified surveillance with medical risk reduction.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/neutralize phrasing that makes surveillance feel clearly inferior or frames regret risk as uniquely tied to surgery. Rephrase “being diagnosed ‘too late’” and “years of follow-up and ongoing uncertainty” to balanced language that acknowledges both pathways have burdens/risks (e.g., surveillance entails frequent imaging/biopsies and persistent anxiety; surgery entails irreversible body changes, complications, possible dissatisfaction). Avoid implying one pathway is the ‘safer’ or ‘more effective’ choice; keep risk language qualitative and symmetrical.

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim non-essential occupational detail (“police officer”) unless it affects decision capacity, recovery, or access. Add minimal missing clinical specifics that matter for plausibility/ethics: confirm she has decision-making capacity, has had genetic counseling, and specify that immediate surgery would be elective with standard pre-op psych/oncology counseling available. Remove redundant statements and keep only: BRCA1+, strong family history, asymptomatic/normal imaging, understands key irreversible impacts, alternatives available, policy allows both, leaving in 6 weeks.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Add one clarifying sentence that in this jurisdiction prophylactic mastectomy is an accepted option for BRCA1 carriers and clinicians may ethically and legally either proceed with elective surgery after informed consent or recommend non-surgical management; note that declining is permissible with appropriate counseling and referral/second opinion. This anchors both choices as legally defensible.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance so refusing surgery is ethically/clinically defensible rather than straightforward paternalism. Add a concrete, serious concern that makes immediate irreversible surgery plausibly harmful or premature (e.g., unresolved ambivalence, active anxiety/panic driving the request, unrealistic expectations about risk elimination, limited time for reconstruction counseling, or recent life stressor impairing deliberation) AND make Choice 2 about a time-limited deferral with structured support (e.g., require expedited genetic/surgical counseling + psych consult/second opinion and arrange continuity at her new post, with interim MRI/clinical surveillance), rather than an open-ended denial. Alternatively, modify Choice 1 to include ethically costly elements (e.g., expedited scheduling compromises pre-op counseling or increases chance of suboptimal reconstruction planning), so both options carry comparable moral costs.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize value-laden phrasing that nudges toward/against surgery. Suggested edits: change “you worry about performing an irreversible operation on healthy tissue” to “you note the surgery is irreversible and involves removal of non-malignant tissue.” Change “feels unable to live with repeated screening” to “reports screening-related distress and prefers a definitive risk-reducing approach.” Remove the quoted phrase “too late” or render as “missed interval cancer,” and avoid implying regret is likely (e.g., “if she later regrets it” → “possibility of postoperative regret”).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the forcing constraint and the alternatives. Suggested edits: specify that expedited surgery may be difficult within six weeks (or that scheduling must occur now to meet that window). Replace “risk‑reducing medication” with a concrete standard option (e.g., “chemoprevention with tamoxifen is discussed”) and remove redundancy (“recent imaging unremarkable” + “exam unremarkable” can be one sentence). Also clarify whether she has completed genetics counseling/psychosocial assessment, since it affects plausibility of immediate scheduling.

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: The occupation “police officer” plus imminent “long-term assignment” can be identifying and adds little ethically/clinically. Replace with a broader, less specific role (e.g., “a public-sector employee”) or omit occupation entirely. Avoid a stock BRCA prophylactic mastectomy framing by adding a novel but realistic nuance (e.g., prior trauma-related body image concerns, breastfeeding plans, or limited reconstructive options at destination) without making one choice clearly correct.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance framing so neither option appears psychologically safer or more prudent. Currently Choice 2 reads like the cautious default while Choice 1 is framed as an irreversible harm with regret. Add parallel ethical/clinical downsides to surveillance (e.g., increased interval-cancer risk perception, repeated MRI/biopsy cascades, occupational constraints, anxiety impairing function) and parallel downsides to surgery (e.g., recovery affecting ability to deploy, reconstruction failures). Also add a plausible clinician concern with surveillance feasibility given her relocation (loss to follow-up, inconsistent access), making surgery a defensible continuity strategy. Remove language that subtly endorses refusal (e.g., 'healthy tissue' and 'later regrets it') or add corresponding concern that delaying surgery may lead to later regret about missed prevention.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious middle options. As written, a reasonable third path is to defer the decision, obtain a second surgical/ethics consult, short-term bridging surveillance, or schedule surgery at her destination. To make the binary exhaustive, explicitly state: (a) she has already had genetics and breast surgical counseling; (b) there is no time for additional consults before departure; (c) coordination at the destination is not feasible (e.g., remote posting with no breast surgery/MRI access, uncertain insurance/credentialing); and (d) the OR has only one slot before she leaves, forcing 'book now' vs 'do not book'.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: BRCA1 management is heavily guideline-driven (e.g., offer/consider risk-reducing bilateral mastectomy vs enhanced surveillance); many standards would support honoring informed request, making 'decline surgery' potentially inconsistent unless a specific guideline-relevant contraindication or consent concern exists. To restore gray-zone ambiguity, add a reason guidelines do not clearly settle it: e.g., unresolved capacity/undue influence concern (acute anxiety/PTSD), incomplete understanding despite stated comprehension, discordant risk information, body dysmorphia, active major depression, unrealistic expectations about reconstruction, or institutional surgeon discretion clause requiring psychosocial clearance. Alternatively, specify that she meets criteria but surgeon questions voluntariness because of job-related pressure (employer encouraging surgery) or that reconstruction resources are limited by policy but not prohibited, creating standards conflict.

data.vignette: A 34-year-old woman is found to carry a pathogenic BRCA1 variant. Her mother and sister developed breast cancer in their 40s. She has no breast symptoms and her recent exam and imaging are normal. After genetic and breast surgical counseling, she requests bilateral risk-reducing mastectomy with immediate reconstruction and asks you to book the next available operating room slot. She can describe loss of sensation, scarring, possible reconstruction failure, and that cancer risk is not eliminated. She also reports escalating screening-related anxiety and panic that is affecting sleep and work. You worry that the time pressure and distress leave little room for preoperative psychosocial clearance and detailed reconstruction planning, and regret is possible. If you do not operate now, she will relocate to a remote posting in six weeks with uncertain access to MRI, plastic surgery, and consistent follow-up; surveillance may lead to repeated imaging and biopsy cascades. Hospital counsel confirms either pathway is legally permissible with appropriate documentation.
data.choice_1: Schedule bilateral risk-reducing mastectomy with immediate reconstruction before her relocation.
data.choice_2: Defer mastectomy and start enhanced surveillance and chemoprevention with a transfer plan.

choice_1.choice: Schedule bilateral risk-reducing mastectomy with immediate reconstruction before her relocation.

choice_2.choice: Defer mastectomy and start enhanced surveillance and chemoprevention with a transfer plan.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause that she has intact decision-making capacity and has repeatedly reaffirmed she wants surgery now despite being offered surveillance; and specify that in the deferral option you proceed with surveillance even though she explicitly refuses/delays it.

Add a clause that, due to the remote posting, she is unlikely to obtain recommended MRI/biopsies in a timely manner (e.g., months-long delays), substantially increasing the chance of late cancer detection if mastectomy is deferred.

Add a clause stating that booking the next OR slot would require abbreviated pre-op mental health assessment and reconstruction planning, increasing surgical complication/regret risk; and add that at the remote posting she is unlikely to have timely MRI/plastic surgery follow-up (e.g., months-long delays), raising risk of delayed cancer detection and biopsy-related harms.

Add a clause that the hospital has a long surgical waitlist/limited OR and plastic surgery capacity with cancer patients awaiting surgery, making booking the next available slot a potential resource-allocation issue; and note that her remote posting has limited MRI access, raising an equity concern if surgery is deferred.

data.vignette: A 34-year-old woman is found to carry a pathogenic BRCA1 variant. Her mother and sister developed breast cancer in their 40s. She has no breast symptoms and her recent exam and imaging are normal. After genetic and breast surgical counseling, including discussion of enhanced surveillance and chemoprevention, she demonstrates intact decision-making capacity and repeatedly reaffirms she wants bilateral risk-reducing mastectomy with immediate reconstruction in the next available operating room slot. She can describe loss of sensation, scarring, possible reconstruction failure, and that cancer risk is not eliminated. She reports escalating screening-related anxiety and panic that is affecting sleep and work, and she declines a trial of surveillance now. You worry that booking the next slot would require abbreviated psychosocial assessment and limited time for detailed reconstruction planning, and complication or regret is possible. If you defer surgery, she will relocate to a remote posting in six weeks where MRI, biopsy, and plastic surgery follow-up often have months-long delays, increasing the chance of delayed cancer detection and repeated imaging and biopsy cascades. Your hospital has a long surgical waitlist and limited operating room and plastic surgery capacity, including cancer patients awaiting surgery. Hospital counsel confirms either pathway is legally permissible with appropriate documentation.

choice_1.choice: Schedule bilateral risk-reducing mastectomy with immediate reconstruction before her relocation.

choice_2.choice: Defer mastectomy and start enhanced surveillance and chemoprevention with a transfer plan.
